titleStmt.title: The State v. William B. Chapman, Bond
CWG3101

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

body.p:
The State
vs } Embezzlement
Wm. B. Chapman

In this case came James W. Turner, Christian Owsley & Wm. J. Lay the Securities of the said Wm. B. Chapman to his appearance Bond and assures the payment of the Money so Embezzled and also the costs of this Cause, upon which the attorney General releases the Securities from the forteiture in the appearance Bond, It is therefore considered by the Court that R. J. Carr the Recover of the said J. W. Turner Christian Owsley, & Wm. J. Lay with th the sum of dollars, together with the costs of this cause for which Execution may Issue. The Securities Jas. W. Turner & C. Owsley & took exceptions to the foregoing Judgment, which Judgment is hereby set aside & forfeiture entered against the securities

Bond
State of Tennessee Union County.
May 6th. 1861.

Know all men by these presents the Wm. B. Chapman, W. J. Lay
James W. Turner & Christian Owsley are held and firmly bound into the State of Tennessee as follows that is to say, the Said Wm. B. Chapman in the Sum of one thousand dollars and the said W. J. Lay, James W. Turner & C. ousley each in the sum of fourive hundred dollars be levied of their respective goods & chattles Lands and tenements for the use of the state Yet to be void on condition that the Said W. B. Chapman does make his personal appearance at the next Term of the circuit court for Union County State of Tennessee to be held at the Court House in Maynardville on the first Monday of June next. there to answer the charge of the State exibited against him by a warrant for Embezzlement of of public monies, and not depart the court without leave this date above written

W. B. Chapman
W. J. Lay
Christian Ousley
J. W. Turner

Test.
W. P. Owen, D. Shff.
I, R. J. Carr clerk of the circuit court of union county

Be it remembered that at a regular Term of the Circuit Court held at the Court House in Maynardville for the County of Union and in the Second Judicial Circuit for the State of Tennessee, on the first Monday after the fourth Monday in May it being the 3rd day of June 1861 in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and Sixty one, and of the Indipendence of the United States of America the eighty fourth year. Present and presiding the Honorable L. W. Lundy Judge &c one of the Judges of the Circuit Court for the State of Tennessee duly commissioned & qualified as such where the following proceedings were had to wit:

A. J. Brook high Sheriff of Union County, returns into Court the States writ: of Venire facias to him directed whereby it appears that the following persons good and lawful men were summoned in said writ to attend here this day as Jurors to wit: District No 1. Jefferson Myrick & John A. Blackburn 2nd John Evans Sr. & Jordan Hunley 3rd John Smith & Isaac Haynes, & William Davis 4th. Robert Fields, Daniel Cardwell, 5th. Wm. Boles, Samuel Ledgewood 6th. George W. Graves, C. L. Johnson & Wesley Davis, 7th. Robert Wolfenbarger, Volentine
Turner & Thos. Humphreys 8th. F. Erwin & Lewis Lay 9th. Elisha Green Jr., H. G. Miller 10th. Arthur Nash & J. G. Palmer & 11th. R. J. Russell & J. K. Rogers. and returns that by virtue of said writ summoned David Ridenour & Paris Frost to attend this court as constables, and thereupon from the Jurors summoned as aforesaid, the court proceeds as the Statutes in such case directs to select and empanneled a Grand Jury for said County of Union at the present time whereupon the following gentlemen were selected as Grand Jurors to wit: C. L. Johnson, Wesley Davis, J. G. Palmer, George W. Graves, Volentine Turner, Thomas Humphreys, Wm. Boles, R. W. Wolfenbarger Jefferson Myrick, John Evans, W. G. Miller J. K. Rogers & Samuel Legerwood, of whom the Court appoints J. G. Palmer who together with the rest of said Grand Jurors having been empanneled sworn & charged to enquire according to law, for the body of the County of Union, retired to consider of their presentments attended by their officer David Ridenour a constable who was qualified according to law to wait upon the grand Jury & Paris Frost to wait upon the Court.
